turns.content:
61. Type "nano filename" to open the "filename" file in the nano text editor.
62. Type "vi filename" to open the "filename" file in the vi text editor.
63. Type "emacs filename" to open the "filename" file in the emacs text editor.
64. In nano, press "Ctrl + O" to save the changes made to the file and "Ctrl + X" to exit the editor.
65. In vi, press "Esc" to enter command mode, type ":w" to save the changes made to the file, and ":q" to exit the editor. To save and exit the editor in one step, type ":wq".
66. In emacs, press "Ctrl + X" followed by "Ctrl + S" to save the changes made to the file and "Ctrl + X" followed by "Ctrl + C" to exit the editor.
67. In nano, press "Ctrl + G" to display the help menu and the available keyboard shortcuts.
68. In vi, press "Esc" to enter command mode, type ":help" to display the help menu, and ":q" to exit the help menu.
69. In emacs, press "Ctrl + H" followed by "Ctrl + T" to display the tutorial and "Ctrl + X" followed by "Ctrl + H" to display the help menu.
70. In nano, press "Alt + Shift + U" to undo the last action and "Alt + Shift + E" to redo the last action.
71. In vi, press "Esc" to enter command mode, type "u" to undo the last action and "Ctrl + R" to redo the last action.
72. In emacs, press "Ctrl + \_" to undo the last action and "Ctrl + G" followed by "Ctrl + \_" to redo the last action.
73. In nano, press "Ctrl + K" to cut the selected text, "Ctrl + U" to paste the cut text, and "Ctrl + W" to search for a specific text string.
74. In vi, press "Esc" to enter command mode, type "dd" to cut the current line, "p" to paste the cut text, and "/" followed by the text string to search for it.
75. In emacs, press "Ctrl + K" to cut the selected text, "Ctrl + Y" to paste the cut text, and "Ctrl + S" to search for a specific text string.

76. In nano, press "Ctrl + C" to display the current cursor position and "Alt + U" to move the cursor up one page.
77. In vi, press "Esc" to enter command mode, type "G" to move the cursor to the end of the file, and "Ctrl + B" to move the cursor up one page.
78. In emacs, press "Alt + X" followed by "goto-line" to move the cursor to a specific line number, "Alt + V" to move the cursor up one page, and "Ctrl + V" to move the cursor down one page.
79. In nano, press "Alt + Shift + ," to go to the beginning of the file and "Alt + Shift + ." to go to the end of the file.
80. In vi, press "Esc" to enter command mode, type "gg" to go to the beginning of the file, and "G" to go to the end of the file.
81. In emacs, press "Ctrl + X" followed by "Ctrl + X" to go to the beginning of the file and "Ctrl + X" followed by "Ctrl + E" to go to the end of the file.
82. In nano, press "Ctrl + R" to open a file for insertion into the current file and "Ctrl + J" to justify the current paragraph.
83. In vi, press "Esc" to enter command mode, type ":r filename" to insert the contents of "filename" into the current file, and "gq" to justify the current paragraph.
84. In emacs, press "Ctrl + X" followed by "Ctrl + I" to insert the contents of a file into the current buffer, and "Alt + Q" to justify the current paragraph.
85. In nano, press "Ctrl + X" followed by "Ctrl + G" to display the current line number and "Ctrl + T" to toggle the display of the line numbers.
86. In vi, press "Esc" to enter command mode, type ":set nu" to display line numbers and ":set nonu" to turn off line numbers.
87. In emacs, press "Alt + X" followed by "linum-mode" to display line numbers and "Alt + X" followed by "global-linum-mode" to turn off line numbers.
88. In nano, press "Alt + D" to mark the current position, move the cursor to the end of the selection, and press "Alt + 6" to copy the selected text.
89. In vi, press "Esc" to enter command mode, type "v" to enter visual mode, move the cursor to select the desired text, and type "y" to copy the selected text.
90. In emacs, press "Ctrl + Space" to mark the current position, move the cursor to the end of the selection, and press "Alt + W" to copy the selected text.

linux lab excercise with real values commands for students to try

Sure, here is a Linux lab exercise with real commands for students to try:

1. Create a new directory named "test" in your home directory.
`mkdir ~/test`
2. Create a new file named "file.txt" in the "test" directory.
`touch ~/test/file.txt`
3. View the contents of the "test" directory.
`ls ~/test`
4. Move the "file.txt" to your home directory.
`mv ~/test/file.txt ~`
5. Copy the "file.txt" to the "test" directory.
`cp ~/file.txt ~/test/`
6. Delete the "file.txt" in your home directory.
`rm ~/file.txt`
7. Search for all files in your home directory that contain the word "test".
`grep -r "test" ~/`
8. Rename the "file.txt" in the "test" directory to "newfile.txt".
`mv ~/test/file.txt ~/test/newfile.txt`
9. Change the permissions of the "newfile.txt" to allow read, write, and execute for the owner.
`chmod u+rwx ~/test/newfile.txt`
10. Create a symbolic link named "link.txt" to the "newfile.txt" in the "test" directory.
`ln -s ~/test/newfile.txt ~/test/link.txt`
11. View the size of the "newfile.txt" in the "test" directory.
`du -h ~/test/newfile.txt`
12. View the last 10 lines of the "newfile.txt".
`tail ~/test/newfile.txt`
13. Sort the contents of the "newfile.txt" alphabetically.
`sort ~/test/newfile.txt`
14. Count the number of words in the "newfile.txt".
`wc -w ~/test/newfile.txt`
15. Display the calendar for the current month.
`cal`
16. Check the disk usage of the "test" directory.
`du -sh ~/test`
17. Compress the "test" directory into a tar archive named "test.tar".
`tar -cvf test.tar ~/test`
18. Extract the contents of the "test.tar" archive into a new directory named "test2".
`tar -xvf test.tar -C ~/test2`
19. Monitor system resources using the "top" command.
`top`
20. Terminate the "top" command.
Press "q" to quit the "top" command.
21. Download a file named "file.txt" from the internet.
`wget http://example.com/file.txt`
22. Install the "nano" text editor using the package manager.
`sudo apt-get install nano`
23. Update the package list using the package manager.
`sudo apt-get update`
24. Remove the "nano" text editor using the package manager.
`sudo apt-get remove nano`
25. List all installed packages using the package manager.
`dpkg --list`
26. Check the version of Linux you are running.
`uname -a`
27. Shut down the system.
`sudo shutdown -h now`
28. View the contents of the system log.
`tail /var/log/syslog`
29. Create a new user named "testuser".
`sudo adduser testuser`
30. Add the "testuser" to the "sudo" group.
`sudo usermod -aG sudo testuser`
31. Change the password of the "testuser".
`sudo passwd testuser`
32. Remove the "testuser" from the system.
`sudo userdel testuser`
33. Change
